posts.com: As I was walking to school I found a cat, I petted it stupid idea) and it bit and scratched me a bit. I am paranoid I will die, will I die? the animal didn't seem too aggressive and wasn't moving weird or foaming... I ammjust scared

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>1314487
Yes, rush to the hospital before it's too late.
t. my cousin is a doctor

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
You need to be calm and not panic, tell your parents about it
It's a mistake to think that rabies is the only disease wild animals can transmit
There's a lot of diseases that animals can carry which can be just as terrible as rabies and you don't want to wait around to wait for the symptoms
You should definitely clean the wound properly, if you don't know how to do it ask your parents
You should then try to see a doctor asap and I seriously mean ASAP
Scratching might be ok but you got bit, that's not something you should take lightly, it can transmit viruses and bacteria through the saliva
Depending on where you live rabies could be a very serious risk or no risk at all but you should still see a doctor

anyways I was bitten by a stray cat once and my hand got really swollen and inflamed, the whole thing, the very day it happened.

>>1314383
1) crop any future screen shots. They're too big to fit full size in a browser window.

2) Second pic shows only one physical device has been found in disk manager. That it appears in device manager suggests driver issues.

>>1314391
>mobo pcie 3x4 slot
>ssd pcie 4x4

3x4 means generation 3, 4 lanes
4x4 means gen 4, 4 lanes
A gen 4 device will work in the gen 3 slot but it will be about half as slow as it would in a gen 4 slot. Gen 5 drives will work in gen 3 slots too, and vice versa.

The first thing, since it's appearing in device manager, is to right click and update driver. You can also try uninstalling it in device manager, detecting new hardware and see if it turns up and installs.

Then exit and reopen disk manager to see it it turns up there, in which case you might need to initialise it.

If that doesn't work I would suggest you turn off the computer, this means at the wall. Make sure you are grounded. If you're in one of those countries that doesn't include ground connections on the plugs you'll need to figure out how to ground yourself. Check that the new drive is seated properly, possibly by removing it and reseating it. (this probably won't make much difference as it's already been found) They don't take a lot of force. They should be screwed in. It should go in the 3x4 slot, not the 3x2 slot which will be slower.

Boot into bios. I don't know your bios so I can't tell you where to find all these options.

You can try turning off CSM and Secure Boot.

Check that the M.2 drive is enabled. It may be with the SATA configuration options and the M.2 options may be like SATA IDE.

Your board has six SATA slots which will probably be SATA 0 - SATA 5. One of them will have your WD details, the other 5 are empty. There will be two more slots somewhere for the M.2 slots. Once of them should be enabled and have the details for your M.2 drive.

If that appears then it should appear in Windows and I don't know what to try if it doesn't.

Good luck.

These COB LEDs almost always have multiple LEDs in series and/or parallel internally.
If 28V is applied to them, then there's probably 6 LEDs in series, times however many strings are in parallel.

posts.com:
>>1314401
>they are in series and provides 5V , it wouldn't turn off (because the first one takes all the voltage).?
To elaborate, I think you're going off series* of false assumptions:
- LEDs are not resistive loads, so they don't work the same way you learned that wires, bulbs, resistors, etc. worked in school. Specifically, their "resistance" goes off a cliff when you exceed their forward voltage forward, or their breakdown voltage backwards. This drop is so steep and so sudden that it's usual to do calculations with LEDs and resistors as if the LED is a magical device that breaks the laws of physics and forces a constant voltage across itself. We subtract the forward voltages of the LEDs, then do the normal math on whatever's left
- you said the driver is a constant current driver. This doesn't actually mean it has a constant current because that's not how electricity works, but its output voltage is regulated by examining how much current it induces. So if you added more LEDs, the voltage would go up to compensate, if you removed or shorted some, the voltage would go down. It's the opposite of a traditional voltage-regulated power supply, where the input charge is constantly monitored by a computer to come up with the same output voltage, instead the charge is constantly monitored to produce the same output current. The voltage produced can vary wildly, even second-to-second.

*hoho

posts.sub: How do you recover data from an android phone?
posts.com:
So my friend has this Moto E that just decided to brick itself overnight. OTA update maybe??? The thing has not been altered in any way and it has not sustained any damage yet it refuses to boot. Fastboot works but it will not go into safe mode or recovery mode. If I try it gives the error "No Command". It wont let me unlock the bootloader either.
The only option I have left is to use the factory defualt flasher provided by the OEM which will erase all the data.

Is there no way to recover some of the data off the phone with it locked up in the bootloader like this? I mean the thing didn't even have a password on it... Surely there is a way?

Model: MOTO E LE UNLOCKED XT2052-1

Does any anon know of a tool that can help?
Thanks.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: the budget moto phones from ~10 years ago were trash. I had a moto g with the same issue. unlocking the bootloader will wipe it, so don't do that if you want to keep the data. if fastboot works, i.e. you get a response when you do "fastboot devices" using the sdk tools, you can try "fastboot boot recovery" and see if it'll get to recovery that way. if it does get to recovery, you might be able to do "adb pull /sdcard/" to grab all the data. but if you can't get into recovery that way, it might be fucked

posts.com:
Decode this: ENT1yWWhLL-Qz9mK

A Twitter snowflake ID is a 64-bit binary number, with 41 bits representing a timestamp, 10 bits representing a machine ID, and 12 bits representing a per-machine sequence number. The snowflake ID is generally serialized in decimal format and is used in the post URL.

For example,
https://twitter.com/i/status/1581674019991916545
Decoding 1581674019991916545:
{'creation_time_milliseconds': 1665935447105,
'datacenter_id': 10,
'machine_id': 337,
'sequence_id': 1,
'server_id': 17}

The filename of a Twitter photo also contains a base64-encoded snowflake ID. This can be decoded into a regular snowflake ID, although it contains three "extra" unknown bytes.
For example,
https://pbs.twimg.com/media/FdMR2WDaMAMPt2q?format=jpg
FdMR2WDaMAMPt2q -> 1572620320212922371

It is unknown if the filename of a Twitter video also contains a snowflake ID. You can see the URL contains it, but any off-platform video would would only contain the file name.
For example,
https://video.twimg.com/ext_tw_video/1564378065198882816/pu/vid/960x720/ENT1yWWhLL-Qz9mK.mp4

How would "ENT1yWWhLL-Qz9mK" be decoded into a snowflake, if it's possible?

Resources:
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Snowflake_ID
https://discord.com/developers/docs/reference#snowflakes (good visualizations, twitter uses another epoch)
https://docs.google.com/document/d/1xVrPoNutyqTdQ04DXBEZW4ZW4A5RAQW2he7qIpTmG-M/edit

However, this would realistically only happen if you contracted one in a third world country and ignored symptoms for multiple weeks. Antiparasitics can also be very tough on the body, so they're not something to use on a whim.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>1314314
>How good is WINE?
It's kind of hit and miss.
A lot of tweaking is often needed to get things running well.

>Does it work the same on all distros or is better on some specific ones?
No difference in my experience.

>If a program isn't there does it mean it won't work, or just that it's a mystery how it'll work?
It could work or it might not.

>Alternatively, how useable would be a Windows VM on linux that would be used only for those couple of programs?
It's perfectly usable, it's just not as seamless as running a program normally.
You have to boot a virtual computer, and at first, install a whole OS in it.
The graphical performance isn't great, unless you use VFIO to passthrough a discrete GPU with QEMU.
Still, it's what I do instead of using Wine.

>My PC isn't very strong (8gb ram, i3-7100 CPU @ 3.90GHz 3.90 GHz)
Your CPU is fine, but you better upgrade your RAM to 16GB.
You need RAM for both the host and the VM.
8GB is already kinda low, even when you're not running VMs.

>I dunno how it could handle VMs.
Running a single VM willl be fine.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>1314236
My old DVD player could play from a USB drive. You could search online and on second hand shops for one.
Or you could get one of those cheap shitty boxes that turn your TV into a smart TV, and that it can also play from USB.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>1314241
>My old DVD player could play from a USB drive.
wow I don't think I ever knew that
Those would probably be limited to standard definition file types, right?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>1314248
I don't remember what it could and couldn't play. The box and manual probably specified it. With Handbrake you can create a preset with the correct settings to convert videos to whatever you need.
This was a replacement player I got in the late 2000s, the previous one didn't have a USB port.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>1314236

A pure display device does not know protocols or data types, it only recieves a signal over one of its ports and displays it. So you can play EVERY kind of medium from any storage device as long as you have a device that can read it and stream it to the TV in format it can understand.
If it's from 2002 what kinds of signals can it accept? Composite for sure, probably also S-Video. Does it have a universal plug like SCART?
You need to find a device to process your video files that can output in a format the TV accepts and has a plug for the corresponding cable into the TV.

>>1314248

That COMPLETLY depends on the player.
The TV just sees its signal. If the player has the capabilities and hardware to decode H.265 UHD and sample it down to a standard S-Video signal you can watch even that. Finrmware updates for new codecs in theory if the hardware is powerful enough could add new file types.

If you only want to change those two buttons, you have two options.
1) change the mapping of the buttons on the PS4 itself (or your computer and emulator), you should be able to do that thru settings

2) Open up the controller and switch the positions of the wires for those two buttons. That way, pressing PS will send the 'share button' signal and visa versa. You probably need a sautering gun for this or at least a lighter

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>1313753
I never used Construct but I've done game development and web development separately.

Does your game have any sort of authentication? If not how do you plan on banning them on your discussion boards, through their IP alone? That's not a good idea because it's easily circumvented and you can get false positives.

>I'd like to inject custom PHP into the exported Construct 2 game.
PHP can't just run inside of a Construct game. It's a server side language. Plus do you really want to distribute your sql database credentials with your game?

The simplest way to do what you want is have your game do a web request to your server, "self reporting" poor play.
I believe in Construct you do this through the AJAX object. Send a POST request to some page you create on your server.
If you got something like a score you can send the score and have the server side script determine if the player sucks. If you got some more advanced logic you can have the game check if the player sucks and send a "I suck please ban me" message to the server.
The server side playerperformance.php code can simply hook up to your SQL server and ban the IP of the player (or whatever credentials they are using to play the game).

This kind of solution will work for most of the players but it's not entirely safe. Someone could flood your php page so you may need to add checks to your ban script to avoid blindly messing with the database.

>>1313600
>dangerous sites can execute malicious code via javascript.
No they can't, that's the entire purpose of a browser. Legacy OS (Linux, Windows) design is intended to prevent you from fucking with the shit of other users on the same computer [pic related]; modern OS design (iOS, Android, UWP) is designed to prevent random untrustworthy bumholes' code that you got of the internet and expect to be able to run anyway from fucking with the rest of your shit.

This is why you UPDATE YOUR SHIT. The security model of iOS and Android is really quite ambitious (Android more so because it makes it easy to install code that's not been through a Store review), and the attack surface is enormous. It's only going to be able to do its job if you keep on top of security updates, otherwise random stuff running in the browser sandbox will be able to use ancient vulnerabilities to get out and mess with your shit.
>my phone doesn't get security updates anymore
You might as well consider it compromised then

tl;dr: javascript stays harmlessly contained inside the browser sandbox, unless you fucked up and disabled security updates

posts.name: Anonymous

Tangentially, the comic was from 2013; back then whilst it had always been known the user/administrator security model wasn't really suited for "automatically downloading and executing random code off the internet", but no-one outside of OSX, iOS and Android development had really given it that much thought. Around that time the issue was starting to become mainstream: "I'm the only person who uses my PC; who cares whether or not malware can access other users when my account has my Steam login and my bank details?".
